entries: Les orcs de sang de démon sont ceux qui ont conclu un accord avec un puissant seigneur démon en échange de leur force. Ce marché implique souvent de servir dans les armées du seigneur démon, de capturer une ancienne relique ou de capturer des créatures qui seront utilisées comme tributs de sang. Ces orcs ont le corps couvert de tatouages lumineux, dont la couleur et le style sont spécifiques au seigneur démon qui leur a accordé cette bénédiction de pouvoir. Les orcs les plus faibles meurent de ce processus, tandis que les plus forts deviennent aussi puissants que dix orcs ordinaires. Une fois leur contact établi, ces orcs conservent cette force accrue et l'utilisent souvent pour conquérir et piller avec une férocité que la plupart des villes ne sont pas prêtes à combattre, jusqu'à ce que le seigneur démon fasse à nouveau appel à eux.

trait.name: Aggressive
entries: Comme action bonus, l'orc peut se déplacer à hauteur de sa vitesse vers une créature hostile qu'il peut voir.

trait.name: Demon's Aim
entries: Comme action bonus, l'orc peut choisir de puiser dans son sang démoniaque pour effectuer son prochain tir. La prochaine attaque à distance de l'orc subit une pénalité de -3 au jet d'attaque. Si l'attaque touche, ajoutez +6 aux dégâts de l'attaque.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: L'orc effectue deux attaques avec son arc long ou avec ses épées courtes.

action.name: Longbow
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 7} pour toucher, portée de 150/600 ft., une cible. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d8 + 3}) dégâts perforants plus 2 ({@damage 1d4}) dégâts nécrotiques.

action.name: Shortsword
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} pour toucher, portée de 1,5 m, une cible. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d6 + 3}) dégâts perforants.

action.name: Volley {@recharge 5}
entries: L'orque effectue une attaque à distance contre un nombre quelconque de créatures situées à moins de 3 mètres d'un point qu'il peut voir dans la portée de son arme. Il effectue un jet d'attaque distinct pour chaque cible.

Ces orcs étaient des archers avant, mais avec ce nouveau sang, ils visent étrangement. Ils se poignardent avec chaque flèche avant de tirer, ce qui leur permet d'infliger de douloureux dégâts nécrotiques à leurs cibles. Ils peuvent aussi puiser dans ce puits de puissance, tirer la corde de leur arc plus loin que prévu et lâcher une flèche qui frappe avec la force de deux.

entries.name: Orcs
entries: Cette section développe la créature orque trouvée dans d'autres publications. Pour plus d'informations sur la sauvagerie des orcs, leurs styles de combat et leurs dieux, veuillez consulter ces autres sources.

entries.name: Demonblood Orcs
entries: Les orcs de sang de démon sont ceux qui ont conclu un accord avec un puissant seigneur démon en échange de leur force. Ce marché implique souvent de servir dans les armées du seigneur démon, de capturer une ancienne relique ou de capturer des créatures qui seront utilisées comme tributs de sang. Ces orcs ont le corps couvert de tatouages lumineux, dont la couleur et le style sont spécifiques au seigneur démon qui leur a accordé cette bénédiction de pouvoir. Les orcs les plus faibles meurent de ce processus, tandis que les plus forts deviennent aussi puissants que dix orcs ordinaires. Une fois leur contact établi, ces orcs conservent cette force accrue et l'utilisent souvent pour conquérir et piller avec une férocité que la plupart des villes ne sont pas prêtes à combattre, jusqu'à ce que le seigneur démon fasse à nouveau appel à eux.

trait.name: Aggressive
entries: Comme action bonus, le minerai peut se déplacer à hauteur de sa vitesse vers une créature hostile qu'il peut voir.

trait.name: Demon's Sight
entries: L'orc a une vue améliorée grâce à son sang démoniaque. Il a {@sense truesight} jusqu'à 30 ft.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: L'orc effectue deux attaques avec son épée longue ou sa lance.

action.name: Longsword
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} pour toucher, portée de 1,5 m, une cible. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d8 + 3}) dégâts tranchants, ou 8 ({@damage 1d10 + 3}) dégâts tranchants si utilisé à deux mains.

action.name: Spear
entries: {@atk mw,rw} {@hit 5} pour toucher, portée de 5 ft. ou portée de 20/60 ft., une cible. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d6 + 3}) dégâts perforants, ou 7 ({@damage 1d8 + 3}) dégâts perforants si utilisé avec les deux mains pour effectuer une attaque de mêlée.

action.name: Precision Attacks {@recharge 5}
entries: Comme action bonus, l'orc puise dans sa vision démoniaque et trouve les points faibles de son adversaire. Chaque attaque d'arme que l'orc effectue contre un ennemi situé dans un rayon de 30 pieds pendant ce tour est effectuée avec avantage.

reaction.name: Demonic Endurance
entries: L'orc réduit à 10 les dégâts infligés par une source unique.

Les guerriers sang-de-démon sont les plus forts combattants de mêlée de tous. Les berserkers ont la puissance brute, mais les guerriers ont la tactique et la stratégie en plus de leur fureur orque naturelle. Ils utilisent leur vision démoniaque pour exploiter les faiblesses de leurs adversaires et peuvent faire appel à une puissante combinaison de sang orque et démoniaque pour que les attaques puissantes soient presque inoffensives.

entries.name: Orcs
entries: Cette section développe la créature orque trouvée dans d'autres publications. Pour plus d'informations sur la sauvagerie des orcs, leurs styles de combat et leurs dieux, veuillez consulter ces autres sources.
Orques sang-de-démon

Les orcs de sang de démon sont ceux qui ont conclu un accord avec un puissant seigneur démon en échange de leur force. Ce marché implique souvent de servir dans les armées du seigneur démon, de capturer une ancienne relique ou de capturer des créatures qui seront utilisées comme tributs de sang. Ces orcs ont le corps couvert de tatouages lumineux, dont la couleur et le style sont spécifiques au seigneur démon qui leur a accordé cette bénédiction de pouvoir. Les orcs les plus faibles meurent de ce processus, tandis que les plus forts deviennent aussi puissants que dix orcs ordinaires. Une fois leur contact établi, ces orcs conservent cette force accrue et l'utilisent souvent pour conquérir et piller avec une férocité que la plupart des villes ne sont pas prêtes à combattre, jusqu'à ce que le seigneur démon fasse à nouveau appel à eux.

monster.name: Overgrowth Ghoul
languages: understands the languages it knew in life but can't speak

trait.name: Floral Fortification
entries: La goule peut utiliser son action pour planter son corps dans le sol et devenir fortifiée ou elle peut se déraciner et reprendre sa forme de goule mobile. Lorsqu'elle est fortifiée, la goule voit sa CA augmenter à 14, sa vitesse de déplacement est réduite à 0 pied et, tant qu'elle a au moins 1 point de vie, elle regagne {@dice 1d4} de points de vie au début de son tour.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} pour toucher, portée de 1,5 m, une cible. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d6 + 2}) dégâts tranchants.

action.name: Root Slash (Fortified Form Only)
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} pour toucher, portée de 10 ft, une cible. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d8 + 2}) dégâts tranchants.

Parfois, lorsqu'un cadavre est réanimé, il est tellement infesté de végétaux que les deux forment une relation symbiotique afin de mieux survivre. Son apparence est similaire à celle d'un zombie, car il s'agit toujours d'un corps ressuscité, mais il a des lianes et des feuilles qui s'enroulent autour de son corps. Des fleurs sortent parfois de ses yeux ou poussent en grappes à partir de son estomac. C'est un spectacle tordu et morbide que de combiner une telle beauté avec la mort et la décomposition.

La goule peut s'enraciner et planter ses lianes profondément dans le sol, ce qui lui permet de tirer de l'énergie du sol mais aussi de l'immobiliser. Sous cette forme, elle peut également effectuer des attaques à distance en faisant jaillir des racines et des lianes du sol et en s'acharnant sur ses ennemis. Lorsqu'il n'est pas enraciné, il se comporte comme un mort-vivant traditionnel, se déplaçant et faisant tout ce que son maître lui demande.

entries.name: Unnatural Manifestations
entries: La symbiose végétale peut être imposée aux êtres humains plutôt que de se produire naturellement. Si un spectre des bois revendique une vie, les plantes pullulent autour d'elle et s'y installent. Lorsque le cadavre se réanime dans ce scénario, c'est parce que les plantes contrôlent ses mouvements et non parce qu'on lui a redonné vie. Ces goules sont sous le contrôle du spectre des bois et font ce qu'on leur demande sans poser de questions, comme tout bon serviteur.

trait.name: Attraction to Fire
entries: Les pyréflies peuvent détecter tout feu à proximité et vont s'y précipiter, en dansant et en faisant de belles couleurs. Elles deviennent agressives lorsque ces feux sont éteints.

trait.name: Illumination
entries: Le pyréfly répand une lumière vive dans un rayon de 5 pieds et une lumière faible sur 5 pieds supplémentaires.

action.name: Spark
entries: {@atk ms} {@hit 4} pour toucher, portée de 1,5 m, une cible. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d6 + 2}) dégâts de feu.

action.name: Flare
entries: Le pyréfly émet un brillant éclair de lumière. Toutes les créatures non pyréfiées situées à moins de 3 mètres du pyréfly doivent réussir un jet de sauvegarde de Constitution {@dc 12} ou être {@condition blinded} jusqu'à la fin de son prochain tour.

action.name: Ignite (1/Day)
entries: Le pyréfly met le feu à un objet inflammable qui n'est pas porté ou transporté.

A pyrefly is a tiny elemental quite similar to a firefly in nature, but the pyrefly is quite a bit more deadly. They obsess over open flames and when they find a source of it they swarm and signal to other pyreflies to gather round with a brilliant display of lights. They will cause the fire to dance with beautiful colors, creating plumes of colored light and flashes of dazzling flame. This display of color is also their way of finding a suitable mate.

entries.name: Separation Anxiety
entries: Once a pyrefly has found a source of flame, it will go berserk if anything threatens to put it out. Ordinarily a pyrefly is friendly and beautiful, but make a move to extinguish their fire, especially during a mating display, and they will go all out with tiny flare attacks. They will set anything and everything around them ablaze and give off warning flares so bright that it can blind creatures temporarily.

entries.name: Omen of Luck
entries: While a will-o-wisp is considered to be bad luck, a pyrefly is considered a sign of good things to come in most cultures. Their mating rituals typically coincide with patterns of beautiful weather and clear, starry night skies, so people come to think the pyreflies bring these conditions. In reality, the pyreflies can glimpse weather in the near future and know when they will have plenty of time to stay with a blazing fire, so they are in fact an indicator of lovely weather.

trait.name: Radiant Aura
entries: The stalker sheds bright light in a 15-foot radius and dim light for an additional 15 feet.

trait.name: Charging Strike
entries: If the stalker moves at least 20 feet straight toward a target it begins to glow with divine energy. If the stalker that target with its impale attack on this turn, the target takes an additional 9 ({@damage 2d8}) radiant damage and becomes charged with divine energies. The first time that target deals damage to the stalker on its next turn, it takes an additional 9 ({@damage 2d8}) radiant damage as these energies surge.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The stalker makes two attacks with its impale or three with its radiant beam.

action.name: Impale
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}12 ({@damage 2d8 + 3}) piercing damage plus 4 ({@damage 1d8}) radiant damage.

action.name: Radiant Beam
entries: {@atk rs} {@hit 6} to hit, range 120 ft., one target. {@h}10 ({@damage 3d6}) radiant damage.

action.name: Resplendent Assault {@recharge 5}
entries: he stalker unleashes twin beams of energy that spiral around the room. Each creature within 60 feet of the stalker make two {@dc 14} Constitution saving throw, taking 18 ({@damage 4d8}) radiant damage for each failed save.

The stalker is of a strange design, with three spider-like legs that are each roughly ten feet long. Each leg has four joints, allowing for superior navigation in any terrain. These legs are attached to an oval-shaped body with a twin cannon mounted beneath. Along the edge of this central body are numerous glowing orbs of light that become supercharged as the stalker approaches an opponent. The cannons on its body can fire blasts of radiant energy at long range or have them rotate around its body rapidly bisect a room with damaging light.

entries.name: Tomb Guardians
entries: After an unfortunate incident involving a necromancer, a small town landed themselves with the problem of all of their dead slowly coming back to life and shambling back towards their homes. They sent men on shifts to defend their graveyards, but sometimes it would be a week between incidents and other times there would be four or five in a single day. After a few deaths, they decided to give technology a try and so they hired a gnomish inventor of great renown who decided to create the ultimate defender against the undead - The Radiant Stalker.

entries.name: A Zombie's Worst Nightmare
entries: The stalker has no flesh to be eaten and each of its legs can easily step through the undead, impaling and usually killing them in a single move. The core components of the stalker are kept high off the ground and away from their reach. Even if zombies do manage to surround it, it can always use its Resplendent Assault to turn them all to ash in an instant.

entries.name: Also a Crypt Robber's Worst Nightmare
entries: While these machines were mainly intended to keep the undead at bay, they also serve the very useful purpose of "deterring" crypt robbers. The stalker will let anyone into the tomb to visit, but if it detects that creature has left with more than it came, it will stop their passage. If the creature attacks the stalker or refuses to put back what was taken, they are met with a swift death with the last thing they see being a bright flash of light.

trait.name: Flyby
entries: The raven doesn't provoke an {@action opportunity attack} when it flies out of an enemy's reach.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The raven has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Lightning Charged
entries: When the raven hits with a melee attack, it deals an extra 2 ({@damage 1d4}) lightning damage (included in the attack).

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The raven makes two attacks: one with its beak and one with its talons. It then summons a lightning orb.

action.name: Beak
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d4 + 3}) piercing damage plus 2 ({@damage 1d4}) lightning damage.

action.name: Talons
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d6 + 3}) piercing damage plus 2 ({@damage 1d4}) lightning damage.

action.name: Summon Lightning Orb
entries: The raven creates a 3 inch diameter sphere of electricity in an unoccupied space within 60 feet. This sphere persists for 1 minute or until the raven is killed. A creature that ends its turn in the same space as a lightning orb takes 3 ({@damage 1d6}) lightning damage. On initiative count 20, the orbs spark a 5-foot wide line of lighting between all other orbs within 20 feet. Creatures caught within one of these streaks of lightning must succeed on a {@dc 12} Dexterity saving throw or take 10 ({@damage 3d6}) lightning damage.

This raven may be small but it certainly should not be underestimated. The storm raven is a lightning imbued bird that has the ability to summon orbs of lightning to destroy its foes. At a glance it appears to be an ordinary raven, but when it flaps its wings small bolts of lightning arc to nearby objects. As it approaches a surface for landing, lightning will spark from its talons to the surface. Even with these capabilities, they behave similarly to an ordinary raven unless they need to defend themselves.

entries.name: Sorcerer's Spark
entries: Similar to a sorcerer, these raven's have their abilities awoken at a critical moment in their lives. This is almost always as the raven is about to be killed be a predator. Some innate power stored deep in the creature, extending back for thousands of years, is unleashed and the raven can they harness the power of the storm. Immediately, the raven grows more intelligent as their mind is opened to the world and they gain a complete understanding of their capabilities.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 2} to hit, reach 5ft., one target. {@h}2 ({@damage 1d4}) piercing damage and the target must succeed on a {@dc 10} Constitution saving throw or the scarab burrows under the skin of the target. A creature may use its action to attempt to cut out the scarab. That creature makes a {@dc 10} sleight of hand check, killing the scarab and cutting it out of the victim on a success. Success or fail, the creature in which the scarab is burrowed takes 1 point of piercing damage from this maneuver.\nIf the scarab is burrowed, at the end of each of its turns it moves closer to the creature's brain, dealing an additional 1 piercing damage. If the scarab is not removed, after 3 turns of being burrowed it latches on to the brain of the creature and takes control of its body until removed. A creature that has a scarab removed from its brain falls {@condition unconscious} for {@dice 1d4} days.

A tiny creature with terrifying capabilities. These beetle-like creatures were bred and raised to be the ultimate guardians within a sacred temple. They do not disturb any ancient relics or the bodies of the dead, live for over a hundred years, and require little to no sustenance to survive. They are small enough to squeeze through the cracks and hidden passageways in the stone halls they call home, waiting for living intruders to make their way into the temple so they can have a true meal.

entries.name: Controllers of Mind
entries: The scarab enjoys nothing more than to gain control of a living creature. It will bite them and burrow beneath the flesh, crawling along under their skin until it reaches the location where spine and brain meet. It then clamps down on this cluster of nerves and gains control of that creature's actions. The victim's mind silently screams out in agony as the scarab feeds on their cranial fluid. The scarab defends its meal by directing the creature to attack its own allies or sometimes to simply flee to a location so it can eat in peace.

trait.name: Illusory Appearance
entries: The terror beast makes itself appear as creatures far more frightening than itself. Whenever a creature attacks the terror beast, roll a {@dice d20}. On a result of 11 or higher, the attack hits part of its illusory appearance and does no damage. Each time the terror beast is successfully hit, it changes form to a new horror. Creatures with {@sense blindsight} or {@sense truesight} can see the terror beast's true form and are not affected by this feature. Whenever the terror beast dies, it reverts to its actual form as a small, seemingly non-threatening creature.

trait.name: Unnatural Insight
entries: The terror beast learns a creature's deepest fears simply by looking at them.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The terror beast makes two attacks: one with Terror Assault and one with Tear Asunder.

action.name: Terror Assault
entries: Target creature within 90 feet must make a {@dc 16} Wisdom saving throw, taking 22 ({@damage 5d8}) psychic damage on a failed save and become {@condition frightened} until the end of its next turn on a failed save, or half as much damage and not frightened on a successful one.

action.name: Tear Asunder
entries: Target creature within 90 feet must make a {@dc 16} Intelligence saving throw, taking 22 ({@damage 5d8}) psychic damage and becoming convinced one of their limbs have been violently ripped from their body on a failed save, or half as much damage and their limb remains intact on a successful one. If they fail the save by 10 or more, they become convinced their eyes are torn out. Even though the effects aren't real, the victim is convinced it is reality and suffer from the same detriments as if they actually lost that body part. This deception ends when the terror beast dies.

action.name: Worst Nightmares {@recharge 5}
entries: The terror beast unleashes a torrent of nightmarish illusions against its enemies. Each creature within 30 feet of the terror beast must make a {@dc 16} Wisdom saving throw, taking 27 ({@damage 6d8}) psychic damage and is {@condition paralyzed} until the end of its next turn on a failed save, or half as much damage and not paralyzed on a successful one. If a creature is reduced to 0 hit points from this attack, the terror beast.

action.name: Face Death (1/Day)
entries: The terror beast infests the mind of a creature within 90 feet with nightmare and forces it to live out its own death over and over, each death more gruesome than the last. Have that player make death saving throws until they reach 3 successes, 3 failures, or rolls a natural 20. If they reached 3 failures, the creature takes 55 ({@damage 10d10}) psychic damage and has disadvantage on all attacks, saving throws, and ability checks for the next {@dice 1d4} turns. On 3 successes, the creature takes half as much psychic damage and does not have disadvantage. If the player rolls a natural 20 on one of their saves, the effect ends immediately with no damage dealt as their mind conquers this attack.

While this entity is called a terror beast, its physical appearance is similar to that of a large rabbit. It has comically large, floppy ears, big green eyes, and is covered in light brown fur. Unlike a rabbit, it does have a set of claws and some sharp teeth, but it is small enough that it can only take small nibbles of flesh with a bite. Even though this is the true form of the terror beast, very few will ever get a chance to see it.

entries.name: Aspiring for Intimidation
entries: The terror beast longs to inflict fear in other creatures, but unfortunately its ordinary form doesn't help the cause. To compensate for this fact, the terror beast is capable of creating incredibly realistic illusions. It also has unnatural insight into the minds of others, uncovering their deepest horrors with a single glance and transforming into them. This often is what causes its opponent's to cower in fear and brings tremendous joy to the terror beast.

The beast is constantly on the move, looking for new victims it can literally scare to death. They will often wander into moderately sized town and lurk in back alleyways, waiting for unsuspecting victims to approach at night. Sometime the terror beast will let these people flee and spread the word that there is some sort of nightmarish creature plaguing their city. The terror beast relishes in whatever decision the town makes - either send these people away as insane or turn to panic against this unknown monster.

entries.name: Psychic Assault
entries: The terror beast uses a powerful set of psychic abilities to attack its opponents rather than its tiny claws and teeth. It can make a victim think that they are being ripped limb from limb, unable to recognize that their body is still in tact and responding to the pain as if it were real. The beast can even cause a creature to live out its own death, unleashing all of their fears one after another and causing them to die from each of them until their mind collapses under the mental strain.

monster.name: The Emerald Queen

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (1/Day)
entries: If the queen fails a saving throw, she can choose to succeed instead.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The queen makes two attacks: one with her shortsword and one with her thorn whip, or two attacks with her longbow.

action.name: Shortsword
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d6 + 4}) slashing damage plus 7 ({@damage 2d6}) fire damage.

action.name: Thorn Whip
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 15ft., one target. {@h}9 ({@damage 2d4 + 4}) slashing damage. The target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 14}) if the Queen is not already grappling a creature. Until the grapple ends, the target takes 10 ({@damage 3d6}) piercing damage at the start of each of its turns. If the queen uses this attack while a target is already {@condition grappled}, she may pull the target to her and deal an additional 9 ({@damage 2d4 +4}) piercing damage automatically.

action.name: Longbow
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 7} to hit, range 150/600 ft., one target. {@h}8 ({@damage 1d8 + 4}) piercing damage plus 7 ({@damage 2d6}) poison damage.

action.name: Hail of Thorns {@recharge 5}
entries: The queen launches a volley of deadly thorns in a 30-foot cone. Each creature in the area must make a {@dc 14} Dexterity saving throw, taking 35 ({@damage 10d6}) piercing damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

legendaryHeader: The queen can take 3 legendary actions, choosing from the options below. Only one legendary action can be used at a time and only at the end of another creature's turn. The queen regains spent legendary actions at the start of her turn.

legendary.name: Strike
entries: The queen makes an attack with her shortsword or her longbow.

legendary.name: Swift Repositioning
entries: The queen can move up to half of her movement speed without provoking {@action opportunity attack|phb|attacks of opportunity}.

Deep in the forest, so far from society that it begins to blend with the realm of the fey, is the Domain of the Emerald Queen. For thousands of years this throne belonged to an Emerald King by the name of Sylarrian - a kind and seemingly eternal ruler who managed the balance between the two planes. Then an elf named Lylia found her way into Sylarrian's kingdom and the two fell in love. As time went on, she began to crave his power. . . lusted for it. The elder fey that give power to the crown decided it time for new leadership if Sylarrian was blind the plot unraveling under his own nose, within his own domain.

She killed Sylarrian with a dagger as he embraced her tenderly, then took the crown and named herself the Emerald Queen,. This title is quite formal for a woman who is more a fighter than an aristocrat. She decided mortals unworthy to pass through her domain and blocked it off with a massive ring of thorns and vines, leaving only one passage into her realm. This passage is guarded by both plant and beast alike. Here she rules with her powerful magic and remarkable skill with a bow, making sure not to expose herself to the same weakness as her former lover.

Lylia is a beautiful elf with pale skin and midnight black hair that wraps around and hangs down over her chest in a braid. Her eyes are a stunning and fierce green, ablaze with confidence and wisdom. She wears incredibly well-crafted green-tinted leather armor, not something expected of a queen but rather a warrior. Hanging from one hip is a silver sword with a gleam of emerald along the edge of the blade and hanging off of the other side is a curled up strand of thorns. The final item is the crown thorns and plant life that wraps around her head, the Crown of the Emerald Queen. It seems painful to wear and her face even appears to be permanently scarred from some of the thorns, but she doesn't pay it any mind.

entries.name: Bound to the Ancient Ways
entries: The power of the crown comes with drawbacks of its own. If anyone wishes to challenge her for the crown, she must leave them unharmed as they go through the Emerald Trials. If they are successful in these trials, she will engage them in combat in her throne room and if defeated must give up her power and leave the realm in shame (if they choose to let her live at all).
You can send your players through the Domain of the Emerald Queen by referring to the Dungeon section of the {@footnote Toolkit|Not yet converted for 5eTools.}.

monster.name: Timeless Chronomancer

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: Le diable a l'avantage sur les jets de sauvegarde contre les sorts et autres effets magiques.

trait.name: Innate Spellcasting Note
entries: The devil's innate spells do not require any components.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The chronomancer uses its Domes of Distortion ability if able. It then makes one attack with each of its daggers.

action.name: Dagger of Ages
entries: {@atk mw} +10 to hit, reach 5ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d4 + 4}) piercing damage and the target must succeed on a {@dc 21} Constitution saving throw or immediately age {@dice 1d20} years and take 27 ({@damage 6d8}) force damage. A creature within a Dome of Vigor has disadvantage on this saving throw. A greater restoration spell can restore a creature's age to normal.

action.name: Dagger of Sands
entries: {@atk mw} +10 to hit, reach 5ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d4 + 4}) piercing damage, and must succeed on a {@dc 21} Constitution saving throw against being magically petrified. A creature within a Dome of Lethargy has disadvantage on this saving throw. On a failed save, the creature is also {@condition restrained}. It must repeat the saving throw at the end of its next turn. On a success, the effect ends. On a failure, the creature is {@condition petrified}. Only a greater restoration or wish spell can restore the creature to normal.

action.name: Domes of Distortion {@recharge 5}
entries: The chronomancer creates two 15-foot radius domes at two locations within 120 feet. These domes last for one next minute or until the chronomancer uses this ability again. One dome, the Dome of Vigor, gives the creatures within the benefits of the Haste spell while the other, the Dome of Lethargy, gives the detriments of the Slow spell. The Dome of Haste is a green in color while the Dome of Lethargy is blue in color. These domes cannot overlap.

action.name: Entombed By Time
entries: The chronomancer conjures an hourglass shaped prison in an attempt to trap a creature within 120 feet. That creature must succeed on a {@dc 21} Dexterity saving throw or be imprisoned. Sand immediately begins to pour from the top of the hourglass to the bottom, causing the trapped creature to age rapidly. A creature that starts its turn within the hourglass ages {@dice 1d20} years. If 30 points of damage are dealt to the glass walls of the hourglass in a single turn, the glass shatters and the hourglass disappears.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The chronomancer's innate spellcasting ability is Intelligence (spell save {@dc 21}). He can innately cast the following spells, requiring no components.

legendaryHeader: The chronomancer can take 3 legendary actions, choosing from the options below. Only one legendary action can be used at a time and only at the end of another creature's turn. The chronomancer regains spent legendary actions at the start of its turn.

legendary.name: Dagger
entries: The chronomancer makes an attack with one of its daggers.

legendary.name: Teleport (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: The chronomancer magically teleports, along with any equipment it is wearing or carrying, up to 120 feet to an unoccupied space it can see.

legendary.name: Entomb (Costs 3 Actions)
entries: The chronomancer uses its Entombed By Time ability.

The chronomancer long ago stopped feeling the effects of the passage of time. He primarily stays within a castle his family constructed thousands of years ago. It rests on peninsula that extends out into the ocean and creates a stunning view. It also makes the castle nearly impossible to siege. From here he has watched the waves erode away the stone and reshape the land into something completely different than what it was when he was a child oh so long ago. Once in an ordinary man's lifetime he will leave and take a few years to explore the world, take note of how it has changed, and collect enough books to last him another 50 or 60 years until he feels the urge to go out and explore once again.

Despite being thousands of years old, the chronomancer appears to be in his mid-forties, this was his age he was when he unlocked the secrets of time magic. He spent every moment of his adolescence and adult life in study and performing experiments. He had a passion and his parents had incredible wealth. They were proud to be raising a scholar and a spellcaster that would shape the future of the world.

His motivations changed when his mother became sick with a disease that no cleric could seem to cure. He put her in a stasis to keep her alive until he could find a way to fix her. Afterwards, he gathered the best healers from around the world and brought them back to the castle, but when he broke the spell he realized the terrible mistake he had made. In her stasis she could feel the pain of the disease the entire time. . . he had trapped her in an inescapable prison of agony for years and her sane mind had long since faded. He would never seem to forgive himself for this and decided that he would increase his own life and continue to live on with this guilt until he has finally made peace with himself. Thousands of years later and this still has not happened.

entries.name: Decider of Fate
entries: The chronomancer has turned the tide in a few wars when he saw it fit for one side to be victorious over the other, stopping time for all but himself and with a single strike of his magical dagger putting an end to a king or general. Stories of the chronomancer and his influence are older than even the most ancient of history books. His exploits are sung about in taverns, told around campfires, and recited at dinner parties. He has written down everything he has done in his life and sometimes the events were so long ago that he gets to rediscover the memories as he reads them in his own books.

entries.name: Hoarder of Knowledge
entries: The chronomancer knows just about all there is to be known in this world, but does not spread it on his journeys. He is there merely to observe and to retain. He has forgotten more than even most elves will learn in an entire lifetime. When someone wishes to obtain knowledge of time magic from the chronomancer, he will demand they prove themselves worthy of wielding such power and engage them in combat - even if it is one against many. Few have managed to pass this test, but he will not spare them death in this combat, knowing that if they are not able to defeat him then they would not have the wisdom to use this magic and would fall victim to the same mistakes he made so many years ago.

trait.name: Innate Spellcasting Note
entries: The witch doctor's innate spells require no material components.

trait.name: Totemic Ritualist
entries: Whenever the witch doctor uses its action to cast a spell, it may use its bonus action to conjure a totem if able.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The witch doctor conjures a totem is able. It then makes two attacks with its claws or two with its blowgun.

action.name: Dagger
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5ft., one target. {@h}4 ({@damage 1d4 + 2}) piercing damage.

action.name: Blowgun
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 5} to hit, range 20/60 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d6 + 2}) piercing damage plus 14 ({@damage 4d6}) poison damage.

action.name: Conjure Totem {@recharge 4}
entries:
The Witch Doctor creates a powerful, magical totem in an unoccupied space within 30 feet. This totem is a tiny object with 15 hit points and AC 12. The totem provides bonuses to the witch doctor and its allies until destroyed. The witch doctor may only have one totem of each type active at a time. When the witch doctor summons a totem it chooses from the following options:
  Invigorating Totem - On initiative count 20 (losing ties), evil creatures within 30 feet of the totem regain 5 ({@damage 1d10}) hit points.
  Empowering Totem - Evil creatures within 30 feet of the totem deal an additional 5 ({@damage 1d10}) force damage on all weapon attacks.
  Impeding Totem - The area within 30 feet of the totem is considered difficult terrain for non-evil creatures.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The witch doctor's innate spellcasting ability is ability is Wisdom (spell save {@dc 14}). The witch doctor can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

entries: Calling to the spirits of the dead and dark inner magics for their power, the witch doctor is unique and frightening opponent. They adorn themselves with decorated masks, paint their skin with intricate patterns, wear the claws and teeth of animals about their necks, and carry pouches upon pouches of strange ingredients for their rituals. A witch doctor seems primitive at a glance, but have a greater understanding of spirits and death than all but the most knowledgeable scholars. They are obsessed with death and what follows, dedicating their entire lives to better understand it.

entries.name: Totemic Conjurers
entries: The witch doctor can reach into the ethereal plane, grab hold of an unsuspecting spirit, and pull it back to the material plane in the form of a physical entity they call a totem. The witch doctor is so well trained in this process that it takes them only a moment to complete the task. These manifestations are unique to the spirit bound and can either give strength to allies or harm their enemies. The spirits the witch doctor uses to complete this ritual do not come willingly and if the totem is destroyed they are destroyed along with it.

entries.name: Forbidden Ritualists
entries: The witch doctor does not show restraint when it comes to their rituals. They will pull over demonic servants, cause plagues to befall local villages, and can even cause the skies to rain blood if they are particularly skilled. Each victim they kill has something to offer in a ritual - hair, clothing, blood, teeth - it all appeases their gods in new and exciting way and can cause unforeseen results. It is not uncommon for the witch doctor to call over a force they cannot control, twisted abominations of realms buried so far down that no one can access them willingly. When this occurs, the witch doctor will throw themselves into servitude of this new force in hope of achieving greatness and power.

trait.name: Locus of Spirits
entries: Whenever a non-evil humanoid dies within 60 feet of the wraith, their body rises as an Overgrowth Ghoul under the wraith's control {@dice 1d4} rounds later.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The wraith uses its Convert Flesh ability. It then makes two vine slash attacks.

action.name: Vine Slash
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}8 ({@damage 1d8 + 2}) slashing damage.

action.name: Convert Flesh
entries: Target creature within 60 feet makes a {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw against being magically petrified. On a failed save, the creature begins to turn to wood and their movement speed is reduced to 0 ft. It must repeat the saving throw at the end of its next turn. On a success, the effect ends. On a failure, the creature turns to wood and is {@condition petrified} for 24 hours.

action.name: Rain of Splinters {@recharge 5}
entries: The wraith unleashes an explosion of sharp splinters in a 15 foot cone. Each creature in that area must make a {@dc 13} Dexterity saving throw, taking 27 ({@damage 6d8}) piercing damage on a failed save, or half as much on a successful one.

Sometimes in order to deal with an evil spirit, it will be trapped inside of an object to serve as a prison. When the object chosen as the target of this imprisonment is a tree, a particularly powerful spirit can exert influence upon it. Over time the tree will decay, rot, and mold into a new form. It slowly changes to appear more and more humanoid in nature until finally the spirit has worn the plant down enough that it can take control and a woodwraith is formed. While the spirit is still trapped, it can channel its corruption through the tree and even raise the dead as overgrowth ghouls.

entries.name: Viciously Spiteful
entries: The wrath's first target will always be the ones who trapped them in the first place. It often takes years for the spirit to be able to animate their prison and during that time they are left to fester with hate and thoughts of revenge. There is a lingering magic within the spirit that guides it to its jailor, and while it is not a perfect guidance system, they will always find their way there eventually typically rallying an army of ghoul followers along the way.

entries.name: Return in Kind
entries: While imprisoned, there is another unintentional negative outcome - the spirit learns how to turn others to wood and trap them in prisons of their own. It does not have the power to cause this permanently, but it finds great joy seeing the ones that trapped it suffer a similar fate. The wraith will imprison their target of its hate and see to it that they suffer by taking their petrified form along as a witness as it converts their friends and family to ghouls under its control.

monster.name: Decaying Zoblin
languages: understands the languages it knew in life but can't speak

trait.name: Undead Fortitude
entries: If damage reduces the zoblin to 0 hit points, it must make a Constitution saving throw with a DC of 10 + the damage taken, unless the damage is radiant or from a critical hit. On a success, the zoblin drops to 1 hit point instead.

trait.name: Putrid
entries: A creature that touches the zoblin or hits it with a melee attack while within 5 feet of it takes 1 necrotic damage.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 2} to hit, reach 5ft., one target. {@h}2 ({@damage 1d4}) slashing damage.

Zoblins are simply zombified goblins. These shambling entities can be a menace when a necromancer operates over the site of an old goblin village or battleground. The zoblins are comparable in strength to ordinary zombies but some with some unique abilities. Decaying zoblins are actively falling apart and will cause disease, an ordinary zoblin will latch on to targets and continue gnawing until their victim is dead, and a zoblin boss is strong enough to retain some of its fighting prowess. The most fearsome encounter one can have with these small undead creatures is in the form of the horde of zoblins which run down their enemies and tear them to pieces with their sheer numbers.

monster.name: Horde of Zoblins
languages: understands the languages it knew in life but can't speak

trait.name: Undead Swarm Fortitude
entries: The swarm fights at full strength until it is completely destroyed.

trait.name: Swarm
entries: The swarm can occupy another creature's space and vice versa, and the swarm can move through any opening large enough for a Small goblin. The swarm can't regain hit points or gain temporary hit points.

trait.name: Plagued
entries: When the swarm hits with an attack, it deals an extra 10 ({@damage 3d6}) necrotic damage (included in the attack).

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The horde uses its pull under ability if able, then uses its gnaw and claw attack.

action.name: Gnaw and Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 0 ft., one target in the swarm's space. {@h}11 ({@damage 2d6 + 4}) piercing damage plus 10 ({@damage 3d6}) necrotic damage, and the target must succeed a {@dc 12} Constitution saving throw or become {@condition poisoned} until the end of their next turn.

action.name: Pull Under
entries: The horde attempts to envelope a creature within its space. The target must succeed on a {@dc 12} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone} and be {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 12}) as they are pinned to the ground under a sea of zombies. This ability can only be used if the horde is above half of its maximum hit points.

Zoblins are simply zombified goblins. These shambling entities can be a menace when a necromancer operates over the site of an old goblin village or battleground. The zoblins are comparable in strength to ordinary zombies but some with some unique abilities. Decaying zoblins are actively falling apart and will cause disease, an ordinary zoblin will latch on to targets and continue gnawing until their victim is dead, and a zoblin boss is strong enough to retain some of its fighting prowess. The most fearsome encounter one can have with these small undead creatures is in the form of the horde of zoblins which run down their enemies and tear them to pieces with their sheer numbers.

monster.name: Zoblin
languages: understands the languages it knew in life but can't speak

trait.name: Undead Fortitude
entries: If damage reduces the zoblin to 0 hit points, it must make a Constitution saving throw with a DC of 5 + the damage taken, unless the damage is radiant or from a critical hit. On a success, the zoblin drops to 1 hit point instead.

action.name: Vicious Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 3} to hit, reach 5ft., one target. {@h}3 ({@damage 1d4 + 1}) piercing damage, and the zoblin attaches to the target. While attached, the zoblin doesn't attack. Instead, at the start of each of the zoblin's turns, that creature takes 5 ({@damage 2d4}) necrotic damage. While the zoblin is attached, that creature's movement speed is also reduced by 10 ft. A creature may use its action to make a {@dc 11} {@skill Athletics} check, prying the zoblin loose on a success.

Zoblins are simply zombified goblins. These shambling entities can be a menace when a necromancer operates over the site of an old goblin village or battleground. The zoblins are comparable in strength to ordinary zombies but some with some unique abilities. Decaying zoblins are actively falling apart and will cause disease, an ordinary zoblin will latch on to targets and continue gnawing until their victim is dead, and a zoblin boss is strong enough to retain some of its fighting prowess. The most fearsome encounter one can have with these small undead creatures is in the form of the horde of zoblins which run down their enemies and tear them to pieces with their sheer numbers.

monster.name: Zoblin Boss
languages: understands the languages it knew in life but can't speak

trait.name: Undead Fortitude
entries: If damage reduces the zoblin to 0 hit points, it must make a Constitution saving throw with a DC of 5 + the damage taken, unless the damage is radiant or from a critical hit. On a success, the zoblin drops to 1 hit point instead.

action.name: Scimitar
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d6 + 2}) piercing damage plus 2 ({@damage 1d4}) necrotic damage.

reaction.name: Lingering Instincts
entries: Whenever an enemy within 5ft. misses the zoblin with an attack, it can use its reaction to make a scimitar attack against that creature with disadvantage.

Zoblins are simply zombified goblins. These shambling entities can be a menace when a necromancer operates over the site of an old goblin village or battleground. The zoblins are comparable in strength to ordinary zombies but some with some unique abilities. Decaying zoblins are actively falling apart and will cause disease, an ordinary zoblin will latch on to targets and continue gnawing until their victim is dead, and a zoblin boss is strong enough to retain some of its fighting prowess. The most fearsome encounter one can have with these small undead creatures is in the form of the horde of zoblins which run down their enemies and tear them to pieces with their sheer numbers.

monster.name: Feral Zombie
languages: understands the languages it knew in life but can't speak

trait.name: Undead Fortitude
entries: If damage reduces the zombie to 0 hit points, it must make a Constitution saving throw with a DC of 5 + the damage taken, unless the damage is radiant or from a critical hit. On a success, the zombie drops to 1 hit point instead.

trait.name: Aggressive
entries: As a bonus action, the zombie can move up to half its speed toward a hostile creature it can see.

action.name: Ravage
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d8 + 2}) slashing damage.

monster.name: Zombie Warrior
languages: understands the languages it knew in life but can't speak

trait.name: Undead Fortitude
entries: If damage reduces the zombie to 0 hit points, it must make a Constitution saving throw with a DC of 5 + the damage taken, unless the damage is radiant or from a critical hit. On a success, the zombie drops to 1 hit point instead.

action.name: Greatsword
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5ft., one target. {@h}10 ({@damage 2d6 + 3}) slashing damage.

action.name: Spew Bile {@recharge 5}
entries: The zombie spews bile in 15-foot line. Each creature in that line must make a {@dc 12} Constitution saving throw, taking 17 ({@damage 5d6}) necrotic damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

trait.name: Innate Spellcasting Note
entries: The azer's innate spells require no components, and their Cure Wounds works on elementals only.

trait.name: Heated Weapons
entries: Lorsque l'azer frappe avec une arme de mêlée métallique, il inflige 3 ({@damage 1d6}) de dégâts de feu supplémentaires (inclus dans les attaques).

trait.name: Illumination
entries: L'azer diffuse une lumière vive dans un rayon de 3 mètres et une lumière faible sur 3 mètres supplémentaires. Cette caractéristique ne s'active pas lorsque l'azer est invisible.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: L'azer effectue deux attaques avec son marteau de guerre.

action.name: Warhammer
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d8 + 2}) bludgeoning damage plus 3 ({@damage 1d6}) fire damage, or 7 ({@damage 1d10 + 2}) bludgeoning damage plus 3 ({@damage 1d6}) fire damage if used with two hands to make a melee attack.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The azer's innate spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 13}). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no components:

legendaryGroup.name: The Emerald Queen
lairActions: On initiative count 20 (losing initiative ties), the queen takes a lair action to cause one of the following effects; the queen can't use the same effect two rounds in a row.

items: Vines erupt from the floor and attempt to envelop a creature the queen can see within 120 feet of her. The target must succeed on a {@dc 14} Strength saving throw or be {@condition restrained}. A creature can use its action to make a {@dc 14} Strength saving throw, ending the effect on a success. The vines wilt away when the queen uses this lair action again or when she dies.

A burst of thorns explodes from the wall and launch at two creatures with deadly precision. Those creatures must succeed on a {@dc 14} Dexterity saving throw or take 17 ({@damage 5d6}) piercing damage.

A magical green energy billows around one creature the queen can see within 120 feet of her. The creature must make a {@dc 14} Wisdom saving throw or or be {@condition charmed} by the queen until she chooses another lair action.
